Sunday's editions of the West German newspaper Welt am Sonntag quoted Stahl as saying he would look into whether there is evidence to begin preliminary proceedings against former East German officials for allegedly supporting and harboring terrorists. Hans-Juergen Foerster, spokesman for the West German federal prosecutor's office, confirmed the report and said there already were ``initial suspicions'' but not enough evidence yet to pursue extradition. Foerster said there was a ``priority'' inquiry involving Honecker; former Minister for State Security Erich Mielke, the head of the secret police; and former East German espionage chief Markus Wolf. Honecker's regime was ousted in October by mass demonstrations. He and Mielke are among several leaders undergoing medical examinations to determine whether they are competent to face prosecution in East Germany on charges of abuse of office and corruption. Of the seven terrorist suspects arrested, one of them, Christine Duemlein, 41, was freed because a West German warrant for her arrest had expired. East German authorities, meanwhile, turned down West German extradition requests for three other suspected terrorists: Werner Lotze, Monika Helbing und Ekkehard von Seckendorff-Gudent. The Interior Ministry statement gave no reason for the action, and Foerster said West German authorities would reapply. Lawyer Rolf Henrich, who is representing Seckerdorff-Gudent and Ms. Helbing, questioned whether West German federal police could legally operate in East Germany. Twenty-four core members of the Red Army Faction are still being sought. Two West German bankers, a wealthy industrialist, a West Berlin judge and a U.S. Army lieutenant colonel were among the people killed in attacks for which the Red Army Faction claimed responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official to Investigate Alleged Korean Anti-Import Campaign
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. official arrived Sunday to investigate whether the South Korean government is behind a controversial public campaign that has resulted in a sharp drop in imports of consumer items. Wayne Berman, a counselor to U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, is to visit South Korean department stores to check the accuracy of news reports that high-priced foreign consumer goods have been removed from shelves and foreign brand-name boutiques have been closed. Despite repeated denials by South Korean officials, U.S. and West European diplomats in Seoul say they believe the government is behind the anti-import campaign. ``We have evidence that Korean officials were involved. It is unfortunate that such thing can give ammunition to trade protectionists in the United States,'' said a U.S. Embassy official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official said that although the volume of foreign consumer goods affected is small, the anti-import campaign is serious because ``it is visible and can affect the future attitude of Korean consumers.'' Imports of consumer goods account for less than 5 percent of South Korea's total imports, which consist mainly of raw materials needed to produce goods for export, according to government figures. The anti-import campaign began because of South Korea's worsening trade balance. The country had a trade deficit of $3 billion in the first quarter of this year and may have a deficit in 1990 for the first time since 1985. The government and media blamed the worsening trade balance in part on rising imports of ``luxury'' foreign consumer goods, although the volume of such products is low. The controversy erupted after some foreign consumer goods such as golf clubs, brand-name clothes and refrigerators suddenly disappeared from the shelves of leading department stores in Seoul. At Hyundai Department Store, owned by the giant Hyundai group which exported 220,000 cars last year, about a dozen boutiques for such foreign brand names such as Burberrys, Bally, Lanvin and Yves-Saint Laurent were closed. ``We did it for two reasons _ low profits and new social obligation,'' said Hyundai's senior manager, Choi Chang-kon. ``We also considered the mounting public sensitivity against a luxurious way of life.'' He denied that the action was ordered by the government but said Hyundai was aware of the government's repeated calls for austerity to cope with current economic difficulties. Lotte and other leading department stores in Seoul also said they were planning to close boutiques or reduce the space for foreign goods. One of the most seriously affected products is the U.S.-made Mercury Sable car, whose sales plummeted with the anti-import campaign. The Sable, made by Ford Motor Corp., became the best-selling imported car in South Korea soon after it was first introduced last October. In the last three months of the year 998 Sables were sold, far more than all other imported cars combined. But sales dropped to 105 in May from 280 in February, 224 in March and 159 in April. Kia Motors Co., the South Korean importer of the car, said it has lowered its sales projection for this year from the original 3,000 to 2,000.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's Production Capacity To Reach 4.5 Million Barrels A Day
DOC.TEXT: Iran's oil minister said Sunday that his country's oil production capacity will rise more than 25 percent to 4.5 million barrels a day in two years. The announcement in Tehran said Iran is spending hundreds of milions of dollars to repair damage to the industry from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Iran's oil industry produces 90 percent of its foreign currency revenues. The minister, Gholamreza Aqazadeh, stressed that Iran would adhere to the production quota of 3.14 million barrels a day set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, even though its capacity was larger than that. Aqazadeh told a news conference that Iran's output capacity in March was 3.3 million barrels a day. He said then that Iran would be able to pump 3.7 million barrels a day by the end of July, up to 4 million barrels a day next year and 4.5 million barrels in 1992. His comments were reported by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency and monitored in Cyprus. Industry analysts say that much of Iran's infrastructure is aging and estimate that modernization to increase its output could cost as much as $8 billion. Iran and Iraq have criticized other OPEC members for violating production quotas and driving down prices _ a practice that costs their flagging economies millions of dollars a day. On Sunday, Aqazadeh blamed Saudi Arabia and Kuwait for fluctuating oil prices. Worldwide prices have fallen below OPEC's benchmark price of $18 per barrel, and analysts have blamed the drop on oversupply. On Friday, the price for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude oil, fell 51 cents to $16.62. The cartel's 13 member states agreed in May to cut their collective output by 1.445 million barrels a day to restore the benchmark price. They set the overall production ceiling at 22.086 million barrels a day. Aqazadeh said Iran will rebuild jetties and reservoirs on southern Kharg island that were devastated by Iraqi air raids. He said a petrochemical complex on the Persian Gulf coast will produce 1 million tons of liquefied petroleum gas ``in the coming months.'' Aqazadeh also said Iran will drill 100 wells in the Caspian Sea, which it shares with the Soviet Union. The oil reserves there were ``completely independent'' of the Soviet fields, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Will CIA Be Able To Adjust To Post-Cold War Era
DOC.TEXT: The CIA is refocusing its operations to look at issues such as international economic competitiveness, terrorism and narcotics, but some experts say the agency is moving too slowly to keep up with changes in the post-Cold War world. The collapse of the Berlin Wall and the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact have tempered the great U.S.-Soviet rivalry and prompted the CIA to undertake a wide-ranging self-analysis to determine what it should be doing and where it should be going. ``The transformation of our intelligence priorities is beginning,'' Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, wrote in an opinion piece in Sunday's editions of The New York Times. ``The congressional oversight committees are working with the CIA to develop an innovative, long-term strategy that sheds cold war priorities and focuses on language and cultural skills and economic expertise,'' Boren wrote. At CIA's Langley, Va., complex in the bucolic woods overlooking the Potomac River, a senior intelligence official said there was ``great debate'' under way about the agency's future. ``There is more intellectual excitement in this building than there has been in years,'' the official said in an interview last week. He asked not to be identified by name. At the same time, the official said the CIA was navigating in ``choppy seas'' that make predicting a difficult job, particularly when foreigners themselves are unclear about their future. For instance, he said no one had a crystal ball to see that Romania and Bulgaria would chose communist governments in their elections. The agency, meantime, is eyeing nervously budget cuts being made by Congress in the Defense Department, where most of the money for intelligence is put, the official said. The intelligence budget, which includes money for the CIA's sister agencies such as the Defense Intelligence Agency and the National Security Agency, was estimated to be about $28 billion in fiscal year 1990. The intelligence agencies want to avoid any proportional hit when defense is pared. ``The intelligence community will be scrutinized,'' said Rep. David McCurdy, D-Okla., chairman of the House intelligence subcommittee on oversight and evaluation. ``I see cuts in those areas that primarily support military functions.'' Covert action _ the area that has brought the agency its greatest notoriety _ comprises only about 3 percent of the CIA's budget. The bulk of the agency's work involves analyzing voluminous data from various sources. Practicing their own form of glasnost, CIA officials and some members of Congress these days speak forthrightly about unique opportunities in 1990 for re-evaluating operations and goals, as well as the daunting challenges. But they insist intelligence needs will not diminish; they'll simply be different. ``The era of the cloak and dagger may be over, but the cloaks are likely to multiply and become even more pervasive in their effort to procure military, industrial and commercial secrets,'' said Sen. William Cohen of Maine, the ranking Republican on the Senate intelligence panel. ``It is time to face new enemies _ drugs, terrorism, poverty, brush fire wars and pollution of our planet,'' he said. And while some spies will come in from the cold, ``many more will bask and flourish,'' Cohen said. Boren agrees. The ``growth area'' is the industrial espionage that is carried out by foreign governments against private U.S. companies. ``More and more, the aim of espionage is to steal private commercial secrets for the sake of national economic purpose,'' Boren told the National Press Club recently. ``We're going to have to know about foreign governments' intentions for oil production levels, exchange rates and trade policies,'' he said. ``We're going to have to protect our own commercial enterprises against the theft of commercial secrets.'' David Whipple, executive director of the Association of Former Intelligence Officers, predicted the intelligence agencies are ``looking forward to a very prosperous future.'' But some observers are concerned that the CIA, a cumbersome bureaucracy, may not be up to the task of retooling its operations. ``I think they understand the pressure and the demands for re-examination and a development of the new strategic plan, but I think they are a long way from accomplishing it,'' McCurdy said. ``I have not been satisfied with the pace of change,'' he said. There desperately ``needs to be a new look at the whole thing,'' he added. McCurdy said he is concerned that the CIA has too few independent thinkers, linguists, women and minorities and ``creative geniuses.'' He complained that the new crop of CIA employees ``all look like Penn State linebackers.'' He said such conformity is counterproductive to understanding a changing world full of people from different races and backgrounds. One example might be the restless nationalities in the Soviet Union. Jeffrey Richelson, author of a recent book, ``America's Secret Eyes in Space,'' said it frequently takes years to develop a reporting network that will allow the CIA to know the ins and outs of, say, politics in Azerbaijan. But the agency is optimistic about the future. And CIA Director William Webster says the man who really counts _ President Bush, a former CIA director himself, has no gripes. ``The president has mentioned that he is pleased with the product he is getting,'' Webster said.

DOC.HEAD: PBS Considering Free Air Time for 1992 Presidential Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The Public Broadcasting Service is looking at ways to provide 1992 presidential candidates and the major political parties free air time beyond the normal news coverage to present their views, PBS President Bruce Christensen said Sunday. ``What we're looking for is the way to increase the political dialogue,'' Christensen said in a telephone interview from Dallas, where PBS' board of directors is meeting this week. Christensen said just what approaches will be used ``need to be worked out over the next few months.'' But he said the possibilities include several ideas recommended Friday to top PBS officials by the John and Mary Markle Foundation of New York. The foundation, which will formally present a feasibility study to the PBS board on Tuesday, has offered to contribute $5 million of the estimated $15 million to $20 million that the project would cost. Developed by Alvin H. Perlmutter, an independent television producer, the Markle study recommends that PBS offer free air time in blocks ranging from 2{ minutes to 15 minutes to the presidential candidates and-or the political parties. The Markle plan was outlined in Sunday editions of The Washington Post and The New York Times. Perlmutter, who has worked for PBS and NBC, recommended creating a ``Voters Channel'' production company to prepare expanded political programing for PBS stations that also would include ``character and competence'' profiles of presidential candidates and an exploration of their debates. Regularly scheduled one-hour programs would be broadcast during September and October 1992, with half-hour programs airing daily the week before the November general election. The report also recommended that the programs include segments examining political ads and party activities in the campaign and the media's coverage of it. And it called for a segment in which voters could voice their views on the candidates and the issues. ``Al made a number of suggestions we'll consider,'' Christensen said, predicting most of the 337 public TV channels in the PBS system ``will sign on to what we are doing.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother Charged in What Had Been Called Suicide
LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: Why? That's what Marcia Biancardi's friends wanted to know long after word of the popular cheerleader's apparent suicide came over Beverly High School's public address system on Valentine's Day. It was a question that lingered until last week, when the 4-month-old case took a rare twist. Marcia's mother was charged with taking a shotgun and shooting the 16-year-old as she slept. ``All along, we just wanted the facts,'' said sophomore Eric Wade, who was a year behind Marcia. ``None of us believed it was a suicide.'' Now the counselors who initially helped students confront suicide are trying to help them accept what authorities say was a homicide. The mother, Susan Biancardi, is charged with first-degree murder and could face life in prison if convicted. Her attorney, Robert F. Peck Jr., says Mrs. Biancardi was linked to her daughter's death through ``innuendo, hearsay and suggestion.'' He entered an innocent plea for her Tuesday. He also indicated Tuesday that he did not think his client was mentally ill and described her as an ``active, loving parent and wife,'' the Salem Evening News reported. ``For some kids there's fear and for some there's anger,'' said Lauren Terry, who counsels students at Beverly High School, about 15 miles north of Boston. ``For a lot of them, it has finally put a closure on a long, long spring.'' When Mrs. Biancardi was arrested last week following an inquest into her daughter's death Feb. 14, it fell into line with what many of Marcia's friends had suspected from the start. ``Even that first day it was very clear that there were questions surrounding the death,'' said Kimberly Wilkins, who directs the community's Project RAP crisis response center. ``And that made it really tough for the kids to start going through the process of grieving.'' Classmates couldn't make it add up. They didn't understand why a well-loved girl with a passion for singing, sports and people would take her own life. Had they missed some hint of suicidal despair? There also were questions about how Marcia manipulated the shotgun to shoot herself in the abdomen, and why, if she pulled the trigger, there was no trace of gunpowder on her hands. ``It's much easier to understand that someone (else) shot a gun. With suicide, we don't understand why,'' said Terry, whose caseload has tripled since Marcia died. Marcia's father, a bricklayer, was not at home at the time of the shooting. But her 14-year-old sister was in the house. Witnesses at the Salem District Court inquest included scores of the girl's friends and relatives, many of whom were familiar with the sometimes stormy relationship she had with her parents. Stephen O'Connell, spokesman for the Essex County district attorney, and police said they had ruled out suicide, but declined to comment on the inquest or any specific problems in the family or between the mother and daughter. ``Yes, we knew her life was not perfect,'' the Rev. Donald Remick of the Second Congregational Church had said at Marcia's funeral. ``Though none but God knows all her pain, we do know that in the midst of the suffering and struggle, a choice was made.'' The choice, authorities now say, was not Marcia's. Mrs. Biancardi was placed under 20 days' psychiatric observation in a state mental hospital. According to James Fox of Northeastern University's national crime analysis program, only two or three times a year, on average, is a mother suspected of shooting a teen-age daughter in the United States. Wilkins said the filing of charges is ``very scary'' for teens in the area. ``Adolescence is typically a time when kids test their parents and then you have a case ... that raises the possibility of a murderous potential in all parents,'' said Wilkins. In the days after Marcia died, her classmates began pinning notes, stuffed animals and flowers on her locker. School officials, following the advice of experts, quietly removed the mementos they thought could romanticize or glorify what at the time appeared to be a suicide. ``Now at least it's not something _ a question _ we have to carry around with us,'' said Richard Cooper, a graduating senior. ``But it's not something we can forget, the loss of our friend.'' Maybe, counselors said, now is the time to remember. Gestures such as the memorial hockey game that administrators vetoed in the winter seem more appropriate now. Students are talking about dedicating next year's yearbook and prom to Marcia, who would have graduated in 1991. ``The kids will need a catharsis now, some constructive way to deal with their grief,'' said Dr. Pamela Cantor, a suicide expert affiliated with the Harvard Medical School. ``They need to talk about the fact that a mother is under arrest.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Madonna, who canceled the first of three engagements here because of a sore throat, performed the second show for 14,000 stomping, screaming fans. Deafening cheers greeted the singer Saturday as she emerged from a cloud of smoke on the elaborate set of her ``Blond Ambition'' tour. As late as early Saturday afternoon, local promoters were still awaiting word from the singer's doctor on whether the pop star would make the Saturday and Sunday night concerts. The phone at Electric Factory Concerts rang off the hook Saturday morning, spokeswoman Julie Vitello said. ``It's been murder,'' she said. ``Everyone's so excited about her appearance and people are just frantic. They want to see her.'' The Friday night concert was the third canceled in the last three weeks by the singer, who started the tour six weeks ago. The throat problem was blamed on a viral infection.

Richard Dysart, who plays a senior partner on NBC's ``L.A. Law'' television series, encouraged real-life Kentucky lawyers to do more volunteer legal work. Dysart, who plays Leland McKenzie on the series, was the keynote speaker Friday at a banquet for the Kentucky Bar Association. Dysart also played McKenzie in a 30-second public service announcement taped Friday for the KBA. Dysart did the tape free in hopes lawyers will follow suit and perform more volunteer legal work. ``I say if it gets one Kentucky lawyer to go out to a senior citizens center and show someone how to fill out a government medical form, it's worth the effort,'' Dysart said. Earlier in the week, American Bar Association President L. Stanley Chauvin told members at the conference that ``L.A. Law'' presented a distorted view of how the U.S. legal system actually works. Dysart agreed Friday night. ``We are an unusual law firm with an unusual specialty,'' he said. ``We specialize in everything. And for a firm with seven partners and three associates, we really do get around.''

Bill Cosby, television's well-known dad, may be a ghost soon, but he was quite visible to tens of thousands of visitors at the Riverbend Festival on Father's Day weekend. Cosby, wearing a Dad T-shirt saying ``Ghost Dad'' to promote an upcoming film by that name, kept many of the 100,000 estimated partygoers spellbound during a 75-minute monologue Friday night, festival organizers said. Part of his routine included asking the audience to ponder the philosophical question of why humans continue to care for their young when animals get rid of them after six months. The star of ``The Cosby Show'' asked for only one prop _ a chair with no arms to be placed center stage, said Riverbend chief Bruce Storey. The festival runs through June 24.

The Kid is 11 years old, 4{ feet tall and weighs 57 pounds. But Charlie Korsmo came close to stealing the show from his elders in the new ``Dick Tracy'' movie. ``Wasn't he great!'' exclaimed the Kid's co-star and director, Warren Beatty, last week after the film had its premiere here. Charlie's first movie role was as Jessica Lange's son in ``Men Don't Leave.'' Initially, he wasn't interested in the role offered by Beatty in the film based on the square-jawed comic strip character. But Beatty insisted, and the sixth-grader from Minneapolis finally agreed, partly because ``I hate to go to school.'' Now, Charlie considers himself ``one lucky kid.'' ``Everybody says the movie will be a hit, so it will probably help my career,'' says the slightly built youngster who professes more interest in becoming a philosopher than a full-time actor when he grows up. ``I would sit around and think a lot _ like inventions and theories and stuff like that''_ and then give advice to others, he says of his real goal in life. School, he says, is ``boring, takes a lot of time.''

A slice of the West will become the South _ at least for a time _ for an upcoming Vanessa Redgrave movie. The little town northwest of Austin is being transformed in a small Southern town in the 1930s for filming of the movie ``Ballad of Sad Cafe.'' Much of the town is owned by singer Willie Nelson. Shooting is set to begin June 25 on the film, starring Redgrave and directed by Simon Callow, an actor who played Salieri in the London stage version of ``Amadeus.'' The film company has put out a call trying to locate a full suite of Victorian furniture to lend authenticity to the film, according to Texas Film Commission officials.

DOC.HEAD: Government-Controlled Paper Urges Doe Resignation
With AM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sierra Leone's ruling party on Sunday suggested that Liberian President Samuel K. Doe quit and leave neighboring Liberia to end the nation's 5{-month-old civil war. The Liberian government and rebels fighting for its overthrow agreed to a cease-fire Saturday in peace talks in Sierra Leone. But Doe has steadfastly refused to resign, the rebel's key demand. The United States, in the past a supporter of Doe's rule, has also urged him to step down and leave the country. More than 1,000 people have died in the civil war. Doe's troops largely have been unable to stop the rebels' advance but did drive them from the country's international airport 10 days ago. The Liberian government and the rebels called for the cease-fire pending further negotiations. Saturday was the fifth day of peace talks in the U.S. Embassy in Freetown. In a statement issued after the meeting, the two sides agreed to resume talks next Monday. Conference sources, including U.S. diplomats, have said little progress has been made at resolving the key rebel demand that Doe resign and leave Liberia. In an editorial published Sunday, We Yone, the newspaper of Sierra Leone's All People's Congress, said, ``How much is Doe prepared to give?'' ``When all is said and done, the solution rests with one man, and the challenge is that of statesmanship,'' it said. Journalists traveling with the rebels say the rebels have had problems controlling their troops since the death of their U.S.-trained military commander, Elmer Johnson, who was killed in fighting two weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: King's Youngest Daughter Begins Career As Minister, Lawyer
LaserPhoto AX1
DOC.TEXT: When the world last looked, Bernice Albertine King was a fidgety 5-year-old in white ribbons, piled sorrowfully in her mother's lap at her father's 1968 funeral. Now, the baby daughter of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. is a serene young woman, newly ordained as a Baptist minister and holder of doctor of law and master of divinity degrees from Emory University. Ms. King, 27, is the only one of the slain civil rights leader's four children to follow her father's career and join the clergy. She has a long-range goal of starting a prison ministry that also would provide inmates with some legal counseling. The broader goal of continuing the sweeping social change begun by her father is not on her agenda, Ms. King explains. But she understands why people would take her entry into the ministry as a sign that she intends to go in that direction. ``That's part of being who I am,'' she explains. ``I've learned to live with that. ``My father was more concerned with sociology, the sociological reasons for behavior,'' she says. ``I am more interested in the psychological. I like to analyze things, to look at how things happened to figure out why they happened.'' Ms. King describes herself as an ambitious but private person. She carries herself with an air so coolly serious that friends often tell her she needs to lighten up. Ms. King said she might begin to do that _ after a summer of reading the Bible, studying for bar exams and interviewing for jobs with Atlanta-area law firms. She was ordained and received both her law and divinity degrees all on the same day last month. Part of her serious nature, Ms. King said, stems from soul searching in her early adulthood, when she ``spent a lot of time running'' from the religious calling she felt at age 17. She thought briefly about a career as a television reporter. She participated in some anti-apartheid protests, went to jail after one of them. She also attended Democratic conventions, represented her church at Baptist assemblies and spoke before the United Nations. But by the time Ms. King earned a bachelor's degree in psychology from Spelman College, she had a clearer idea of what she wanted to do in life. She then enrolled at Emory and, in 1988, gave a trial sermon that whipped into a weeping frenzy the congregation at Ebenezer, the Baptist church presided over by both her father and grandfather. At her ordination, the Rev. Joseph L. Roberts, Ebenezer's pastor and one of Ms. King's instructors at Emory, said she has ``not only the oratorical gifts of her father but the sensitivity of her father.'' Ms. King said she considered taking broadcasting courses to sharpen that powerful speaking ability. ``I always felt I needed to work on the way I choose words. I still have difficulty with that,'' she said. ``And I've always admired the way (broadcasters) speak.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Vaccine Available by End of Decade, Government Expert Says
DOC.TEXT: A vaccine to combat the AIDS virus likely will be available for widespread use by the end of the decade, a government AIDS expert said Sunday. The Bush administration has come under fire from AIDS activists and congressional critics for not spending enough money on AIDS research and moving too slowly in approving new drugs to fight the disease. The federal government is spending $1.16 billion in the current fiscal year on AIDS research and the administration has recommended an increase to $1.245 billion in fiscal 1991. But Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of AIDS research at the National Institutes of Health, said Sunday that ``the decade of the '90s will see some important advances that will have a positive impact on HIV-infected individuals.'' ``Over the next several years, you'll see a real acceleration of vaccine development, and hopefully by the end of the 1990s there will be a vaccine that is available for widespread use,'' Fauci said. An estimated 1 million Americans are believed to be infected by HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, which can develop into the AIDS disease. Fauci appeared on the ABC-TV program ``This Week With David Brinkley'' in advance of the sixth international AIDS conference, which starts Wednesday in San Francisco. The conference, billed as the largest gathering to date of HIV scientists, health care workers and policy-makers, will run through June 24. The meeting will be boycotted, however, by 80 organizations because of U.S. immigration policy that bars entry to people infected with the HIV virus. The Immigration and Naturalization Service in April relaxed the ban by allowing 10-day visas for conference participants, but some groups feel that is not sufficient. A pre-conference demonstration is planned Tuesday outside the immigration office in San Francisco's financial district. While conceding that a cure for AIDS hasn't been found, Fauci said ``at least a couple of drugs'' have been shown effective in delaying the full symptoms of the disease in patients at the earlier stages. Dr. Luc Montagnier, an AIDS researcher at France's Pasteur Institute who also appeared on the Brinkley show, said it will take at least four to five years to develop an effective vaccine. Montagnier said government funding for AIDS research in the United States has been ``enormous'' in the past two years or so compared with Europe. Fauci said ``we're already starting to see positive spinoffs'' from AIDS research, such as information that can be used in work on cancer and studies of the immune system. The AIDS conference, which coincides with the annual Gay Pride Week, is sponsored by the World Health Organization, the University of California at San Francisco, the American Foundation for AIDS Research and the city-county of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Raises Issue of Immediate Unity But Postpones Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series, UPDATES with quotes, ADDS Kohl's purpose at meeting. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Flirting with history on an emotional anniversary, East Germany's Parliament came dramatically close Sunday to dissolving the country and uniting with West Germany. But the stunning move turned out to be more a symbolic gesture and acknowledgment that unification was imminent and inevitable. The country's first freely elected Parliament voted overwhelmingly to discuss the final decision of German unification, but then put off the historic decision that would automatically result in immediate unification. Lawmakers met in a rare Sunday session to debate unification and commemorate the 37th anniversary of a failed attempt by East German workers to overthrow Soviet rule. With Chancellor Helmut Kohl and other top West German officials in the hall to mark the anniversary, lawmakers from the German Social Union proposed the final question of German unification be placed on the agenda. ``The Parliament would like to decide: Resolve to join the German Democratic Republic ... to the Federal Republic of Germany on this very day,'' lawmaker Hans-Guenther Schwarz of the German Social Union told the chamber. Lawmakers voted 267-92, with seven abstentions, to take up the issue. But when debate opened, East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere took the microphone and said he would not support the measure because of the many questions that need to be addresed before the two Germanys are united. De Maiziere also referred to the June 17, 1953, uprising, in which an estimated 300 people were killed, as one of the earliest attempts to unify a nation cut in two by World War II. He portrayed the Parliament's action more as a message to the world as the way German unity will take place. ``It appears therefore on this day good and right, to clearly acknowledge German unity and to describe the way that this will be done,'' he said in remarks that were greeted with a standing ovation. Lawmakers then voted by an overwhelming show of hands to postpone the vote on unification, which is likely to come in the months ahead. The two German states are to merge their economies July 2, when the West German mark becomes the currency of East Germany. Banks stayed open through the weekend and hundreds stood in lines, opening accounts and filling out forms so their money can be changed to West German marks. But the two nations still must find ways to merge their vastly different legal, economic and social systems, and resolve the key question of the strategic future of a united Germany. The superpowers are to hold talks in East Berlin on Thursday on the worldwide implications of German unity. The United States insists that it be a part of NATO, while the Soviet Union is staunchly opposed. East Germany also is expected to face high unemployment as it moves to a free market and its aging enterprises are forced to compete. The question that lawmakers voted to put on the agenda for discussion was whether to support Article 23 of the West German constitution, a method under which the entire country could dissolve itself and become a part of West Germany. The article was written after World War II to allow individual sections of disputed German territory to decide whether to become a part of postwar West Germany. Kohl and de Maiziere both have supported the article as the constitutional tool under which East Germany could most quickly unite with the West. Another method favored by other officials would involve both countries dissolving themselves and writing a new constitution to form a completely new nation, which would take considerably longer. However, when unification comes, it will likely occur when East German lawmakers vote in favor of Article 23. De Maiziere's Christian Democratic Union finished an overwhelming first in East Germany's first free elections on March 18 by promising to support Article 23. But an actual vote on it was not expected for months after the economic union of the two nations takes place on July 2. The original purpose of Sunday's parliamentary session was to debate changes in the East German constitution that would make it easier for the two nations to merge their vastly different social structures. However, a broad-based group of left-leaning lawmakers proposed that East Germany merely adopt the laws of West Germany by annexing itself to West Germany via Article 23. The lawmakers dropped the proposal after consultations with their parties, but the German Social Union then came in with its own, similar proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Panel Seeks Gramm-Rudman Repeal; Cut In Payroll Tax
DOC.TEXT: America's mayors Sunday gave initial approval to a broad, costly domestic agenda that asks Congress to repeal the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law and cut Social Security taxes for nearly 120 million workers. The more than 70 resolutions approved by the U.S. Conference of Mayors key policy committee contain repeated pleas for a multibillion-dollar infusion of federal funds for anti-drug, housing, education and anti-poverty programs. Also endorsed was a resolution asking Washington to give cities broad powers to regulate billboards alongside federal roads. But the panel balked at a proposal that would have put the mayors on record as opposing alcohol and tobacco advertising. The resolutions endorsed Sunday will go before the full conference of more than 200 mayors Wednesday. But the panel's decisions are rarely changed significantly in those votes, which set the lobbying agenda for the organization's Washington staff. The mayors, who have spent much of the first three days of their six-day annual meeting criticizing the federal government for slashing aid to cities, said repealing Gramm-Rudman would force lawmakers to confront the deficit. ``Too many of our members of Congress are using this as a crutch to hide some of the true problems of our economy,'' said Mayor Paul Soglin of Madison, Wis. ``A series of budget gimmicks have been implemented.'' Under Gramm-Rudman, automatic spending cuts take effect if Congress and the White House do not meet specified deficit reduction targets. The mayors complained that city-level services are the first to feel the automatic cuts. ``It has the effect of putting cities and towns, urban programs, first on the chopping block,'' said Mayor John K. Bullard of New Bedford, Mass. Conference staff said the mayors group _ if the full conference endorses the proposal as expected _ would be the first organization of elected officials to call for repeal of Gramm-Rudman. Several mayors said the organization likely will face criticism for its stance because Gramm-Rudman is the only mandatory deficit-reduction mechanism. ``The mayors across this nation have got to say this is a charade,'' said Mayor Lee Robinson of Macon, Ga. ``We've got to say enough is enough.'' In calling for the Social Security payroll tax to be cut from 7.65 percent to 6.71 percent, the mayors panel also called on Congress to remove the cap on outside earnings of Social Security recipients and stop using the balance in the Social Security trust fund to mask the true size of the federal deficit. Also included in one tax-related resolution approved Sunday was a statement opposing a capital gains tax cut favored by President Bush. Throughout this year's meeting, big-city mayors have been urging their colleagues to be more militant in their lobbying of Washington and to lay claim to a good chunk of expected defense savings by warning that urban tensions are reaching a boiling point because of cash-poor anti-poverty programs. The first resolution dealing with billboards passed with little discussion. It called on Congress to transfer to the states the power to regulate and remove billboards alongside federal highways. But the proposal to put the mayors on the record in favor of a ban on alcohol and drug advertising was derailed a day after it was endorsed by a lower-level committee as part of a minority-health initiative. Support for the measure eroded Sunday after the measure was amended to oppose all alcohol and tobacco ads. It intially had sought a ban only on outdoor ads. Also scuttled Sunday was a bid by some mayors to call for a constitutional amendment that cities receive a ``fair and fixed'' percentage of federal revenues if Congress refuses to pass a law mandating the revenue sharing. That idea had sparked a split Satuday between conference committees on human development and urban economic policy, with the latter group prevailing in getting the amendment language deleted.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Couples Renew `I Do's' En Masse
DOC.TEXT: Thirty couples who have been married from seven months to 44 years said ``I do'' again as they gathered for a ``Lovers Weekend'' at a resort in this western Maine town. The couples from all over New England repeated their vows at a non-denominational, 10-minute service arranged by the Poland Springs Inn. For Frank and Dottie Stewart of Beverly, Mass., it was their fourth marriage renewal since their first wedding in 1943 in Virginia. ``We're lovers,'' they said. The ceremony Saturday came on the 33rd anniversary of Catherine and Edward Dufresne's wedding in Haverhill, Mass. ``We're still in love,'' he said. Said Mrs. Dufresne, ``We just couldn't pass up this opportunity.'' Bill Kazakis and his wife, Joan, of Manchester, N.H., said the Maine ceremony ``was a chance to say `I don't.''' But they didn't.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Has Been Pressing for Unity, But Motion Came As Apparent Surprise
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has been pushing harder than anyone for German unity, but even his government seemed stunned Sunday by East German debate on an immediate merger with West Germany. ``This has caught everyone by surprise. No one expected this,'' said a West German government spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. The East German Parliament overwhelmingly voted to take up the merger issue, but then decided to postpone a final vote. Kohl, who attended the remarkable session to commemorate the 37th anniversary of a failed East German uprising against Communist rule, has been the chief architect of the German unity process. He announced a 10-point program in November that laid the foundations for unity and he orchestrated the coming July 2 economic merger. More recently, he has been pushing for the election of a single German government as early as December. But not even Kohl had predicted East Germany might consider annexing itself to his country so soon. Kohl has clearly stated he wants formal unity to occur this year. However, he has cautiously avoided making it look like he is trying make decisions for the East German government. During the past two weeks, every time Kohl has been asked when all-German elections might occur, he has said that's also a question the East German government must decide. Last week, he was pointing out that his government has not even begun formal talks with East Berlin about the possibility of joining the two nations under Article 23 of the West German constitution. ``Most certainly we will have to talk about these questions _ what arises from Article 23 and about an election date,'' Kohl said Tuesday. If the East German parliament had approved Article 23, the country would have automatically joined West Germany. Kohl's government has been examining two possible models for unification: all-German elections as early as December, with a simultaneous merger of the two countries; or annexation of East Germany under Article 23 with all-German elections at some later date. East Germany has not expressed an official view about either of these options, and Kohl's government apparently has not decided which one it favors. Immediate unity could also anger the Soviet Union, which has 380,000 troops on East German soil and does not want to pull them back until it can build adequate housing and find jobs for the soldiers. Also, Moscow objects to a Western proposal that a united Germany be a member of NATO. A hasty annexation of East Germany while the military allegiance question is still in dispute would probably create further Soviet concerns. Kohl has told the Soviets many times he wants domestic as well as global complications of unification cleared up as soon as possible.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Constitutional Article to Merge German States
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The constitutional article at the core of East Germany's stunning consideration Sunday to immediately join West Germany has existed since the founding of separate German states in 1949. Article 23 was always viewed as a means toward eventual reunification of the German people, although that seemed only a remote possibility more than 40 years ago. In East Berlin on Sunday, the East German parliament overwhelmingly voted to consider the provision but then put off a vote. Under the article, a region must simply vote to dissolve and join West Germany to become part of the country, with West Germany's constitution and laws prevailing. Article 23 was written _ with the approval of the three victorious World War II western Allies, the United States, Britain and France _ to allow individual sections of disputed German territory to decide whether to become a part of postwar West Germany. East German Prime Minister Lothar De Maiziere's Christian Democratic Union finished an overwhelming first in East Germany's first free elections in March by promising to support Article 23. As translated into English, Article 23 reads: ``This Basic Law (Constitution) applies first of all in the regions of the states of Bavaria, Bremen, greater Berlin, Hamburg, Hessen, Lower Saxony, North Rhein Westphalia, Rheinland Palatinate, Schleswig Holstein, Wuerttemberg-Baden and Wuerttemberg-Hohenzollern. In other parts of Germany it is to become effective after their accession.''

DOC.HEAD: State Law Takes Lottery Winnings for Child Support Payments
DOC.TEXT: One $5,000 winner in the state lottery lost the entire prize for being behind in child support payments, and two others lost part of their winnings, state officials say. Since 1987, a state law passed when the lottery was created has cost three winners nearly $7,000, lottery officials said last week. Deb Mortenson, public information director for the state Lottery Commission, said last week that she can't release the names of the winners who were penalized, but she did give some details. In addition to the $5,000 winner who lost it all, a $7,000 winner lost $460 and a $4,000 winner lost $721. The state Department of Social Services passed the money on to the families. The lottery, which features scratch-off tickets, began in September 1987. Generally speaking, the top prize in the scratch-off game is $10,000 or less. A provision in state law approved with the lottery authorization allows the deductions. It applies only to winners of $100 or more who have court judgments against them. The lottery automatically checks records in the Social Services department to compare the names of big prize winners against a list of names and Social Security numbers. People who were overpaid for food stamps or Aid to Dependent Children programs are on the list, too, said Social Services Secretary Jim Ellenbecker. ``The only three we've had so far were for delinquent child support,'' Mortenson said. ``And the only reason people are on that computer file is that they have a court order against them.'' Other states collect those debts through their state income tax programs, Ellenbecker said. Since South Dakota doesn't have a state income tax, the lottery is just another way of getting that money. ``When the lottery legislation was passed, somebody had the foresight to tack that on,'' Ellenbecker said. The amount garnished so far, however, is small compared with the $40 million in delinquent support payments Ellenbecker said the state is trying to collect. Some of that goes back a number of years.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Guerrillas Kill Seven in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Communist guerrillas ambushed a jeep carrying government troops Sunday in a remote village on Negros island in the central Philippines, killing seven people, the military said. A military report said two policemen, two militiamen and three civilians were slain when 35 New People's Army guerrillas opened fire on the jeep from a sugar cane field near the town of Canayan, 340 miles southeast of Manila. Two people were wounded in the attack and another escaped unhurt, the report said. The insurgents fled with the victims' weapons, it said. The New People's Army has been waging a 21-year-old insurgency to establish a Marxist state.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Drug Publication For Young People Making Debut
DOC.TEXT: A free tabloid newspaper with an anti-drug message aimed at young people will be making its debut this week. Organizers hope RAVE, initially to be distributed through schools and some commercial outlets in New South Wales state and the Australian Capital Territory, will become a national youth publication. It is being funded by the New South Wales' Quit For Life campaign and the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, but also aims to attract commercial advertising. ``With community concern running high about the use of both legal and illegal drugs by young people, RAVE opens up opportunities for business to make a contribution to drug education,'' said Quit for Life spokesman Terry Slevin. Slevin said RAVE has a ``streetwise style'' and avoids using heavy-handed tactics in talking to youth about drinking and drugs. The first 24-page issue will have a print run of 400,000. The organizers hope to make it a monthly or bimonthly, depending on reader and advertiser response.

DOC.HEAD: Two Valuable Italian Violins Stolen at Tokyo University
DOC.TEXT: Two Italian violins, together worth more than $130,000, were stolen from practice rooms of a university during the past two weeks, police said Sunday. Police said they suspected people associated with the university committed the separate thefts at the Tokyo National University Of Fine Arts and Music. A police spokesman said a student left her $26,600 violin on a table in a practice room Friday, and instrument was gone when she returned 90 minutes later. Another student left her $106,400 violin in a practice room on June 5 for a five-minute trip to the bathroom but found it gone upon her return, police said. Her violin was crafted by Joannes Gagliano of Italy in 1803, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Fledgling Falcon Causes Stir When It Disappears From Perch
DOC.TEXT: A peregrine falcon chick that became an instant cable TV star at hatching five weeks ago had viewers panicking when he disappeared from his nest on the 21st floor of a downtown skyscraper. The moment-to-moment activities of the chick and his brother have been the subject of 24-hour cablecast here since they hatched in early May. Their mother and father also are part of the show. The camera has caught each stage of the chicks' progress as they quickly grew to almost their parents' size and started to test their wings and venture from their nest on a ledge of the Monarch Place office tower. But viewers' delight turned to worry Saturday when one chick disappeared. It later turned out that the chick, apparently on his first flight, strayed too far from home and could not make it back. He eventually landed in the middle of a downtown intersection, amidst motorists and hundreds of pedestrians attending an outdoor food festival. ``He was pretty stressed out, there were hundreds of people there,'' said Steve Harris, a veterinarian who happened to pass by. ``He was panting a bit, which falcons do, but he didn't fight us much. He didn't know enough to fight.'' Harris took the chick to the Rowley Memorial Animal Hospital, where he was pronounced in good health. On Sunday, state wildlife officials returned him to a patio several stories above his nest _ to avoid having a human climb the glass-sided building and face wrathful falcon parents. Harris said the parents probably would find their prodigal son on the patio and feed him. But his homecoming would likely be short-lived. ``He'll probably try flying again in a few days anyway,'' Harris said. ``This time he'll probably be more successful.'' The growing chicks lately had been straying beyond the camera's view more and more, but when the bird was out of sight for several hours, worried viewers started calling the cable company. ``People get very caught up in this,'' said Brian Lambert, general manager of Continental Cablevision, which he said is seen in about 100,000 homes. The chicks are the second pair raised on the ledge in this city of about 152,000 people. Last year the same parent falcons chose that spot to raise the first two chicks in 50 years to be hatched in western Massachusetts.

DOC.HEAD: Brass Band Festival Attracts Eight Old-Time Ensembles
DOC.TEXT: In the good old days, just about every American town had its own brass band. During the first-ever Great American Brass Band Festival, which ended Sunday, this south-central Kentucky town was lucky enough to have eight old-time ensembles. ``It was a real coup for Danville and I hope it's done every year,'' said Steele Gregory, a Danville businessman. Activities at the Centre College campus in town began Thursday. They ranged from displays of antique bicycles to a hot-air balloon race, a traveling cartoon art exhibit from the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., an old-fashioned picnic and even a Civil War battle re-enactment. But the highlight of the weekend was, of course, the music. The groups spanned styles and periods, with the Civil War-era Regiment Band of the 11th North Carolina Troops playing opposite Danville's Advocate Brass Band, vintage 1890. Other ensembles included Saxton's Cornet Band from Lexington, the Commonwealth Brass Band from Louisville, and the Brass Band of Columbus from Ohio. But the Olympia Brass Band from New Orleans came the farthest and got the biggest response. When the group led a procession down Main Street on Saturday to the tune of ``When the Saints Come Marching in,'' some spectators fell in behind and danced along. Milton Batiste, one of the band members, said afterward that it wasn't necessary to go to New Orleans to capture that atmosphere. ``The atmosphere of this music can be experienced in Danville, Ky., or New Orleans, La., just the same, providing people enjoy it,'' said Milton Batiste, one of the band members. ``If people enjoy what we do, the atmosphere is right anywhere we play.'' Organizers estimated that more than 10,000 people turned out for Saturday's parade and concert series. Danville Police Chief Mike Lamb estimated that several thousand attended an open-air musical church service Sunday morning. People came from as far away as Maine and Wisconsin, organizers said.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Party Conference Showcase for Communist Disputes
DOC.TEXT: In a preview of a key national congress, Communist Party members from the nation's biggest republic are holding their own meeting this week. It is likely to turn into a battleground over the future of communism and the country under Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The congress opening Tuesday is likely to found a Communist Party of Russia, distinct from the national party. Previously, Russian Republic Communists have been folded into the national organization. While Russia's popularly elected congress elected reformer Boris N. Yeltsin president of the republic and declared sovereignty for the republic itself, the republic's party members seem to have little such independent feeling. Yet the same disputes over economic and social policies and the party's future that are tearing at national party unity will be present at the meeting of the 2,700 Russian Communists. Russia, with more than half of the Soviet population and three-quarters of its territory, is home to 58 percent of the country's more than 18 million Communist Party members. But since the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917, Russia's identity largely has been submerged in the trappings of Soviet socialism. Even though each of the other Soviet republics has had its own party organization within the national party, Russia has not, largely because Russians had tended to dominate the national and republic Communist parties. Its search for an identity has now taken it in the direction of founding its own Communist Party, as well as in the direction of Yeltsin's more radical reforms. Conservatives, radical reformers and the party leaders understand that the Russian party's size makes it vital. The 2,700 party members from the Russian republic are the same group that will represent it when the Soviet Communist Party opens its 28th national congress on July 2. The daily Moskovsky Komsomolets called this week's conference a ``general rehearsal'' for the congress of 4,700 party members from throughout the Soviet Union. Many party members and observers believe the national congress will result in the first split in the party since Lenin. At a meeting June 9-10 in Leningrad, some members called for Gorbachev and his chief party adviser, Alexander N. Yakovlev, to be thrown out of the party, the daily Komsomolskaya Pravda reported Thursday. The Leningrad group says it represents at least 1.5 million party members. It has proposed its own platform and its own slate for the Central Committee. Gorbachev's Communist Party ``has to take responsibility for the results of perestroika,'' Viktor Tyurkin, a 39-year-old Leningrad party leader, said in an interview. ``It is not oriented to the majority of simple working people.'' Like several generations of Communists before them, Tyurkin and his comrades believe that Soviet socialism has protected working people from the whims of the market. While reformers criticize Gorbachev's economic program for timidity in a time of crisis, the Leningrad group sees in them a breach of faith. Despite the Leningrad group's criticism of Gorbachev, there is a strong possibility that it will form an alliance with the national party leadership at the conference, said Vladimir Lysenko, a leader of the reform-minded Democratic Platform. A few months ago, Gorbachev spoke out against the founding of the Russian party before the national party congress but he now favors it, Lysenko told the Moskovsky Komsomolets newspaper. The Leningrad group also favors it. Representatives of the Leningrad meetings have been invited to help write the conference documents but no members of Democratic Platform have been invited, Lysenko said. Democratic Platform is preparing its own set of documents that its small group of delegates will present at the conference, he said. Vladimir Komarov, a spokesman for the Leningrad group, said it will have at least 25 delegates to the national conference. Members of the Democratic Platform say they expect to have a small group as well. Soviet party leaders have given no indication so far what direction they think the party should take. Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, another Democratic Platform leader, said that even though organizers of the Leningrad meetings do not have any influential nationwide leaders, they can reach a large number of Russians frustrated by the failures of reform. By such appeals, ``a bloc can be formed that can create a rather potent threat to political stability,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Fight Between Supporters and Rivals of Abu Nidal
DOC.TEXT: Rival factions of the guerrilla group led by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal battled Sunday with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, killing at least four people and wounding 15, police said. The showdown was the bloodiest in Lebanon between the two factions since an anti-Abu Nidal mutiny within his Fatah-Revolutionary Council began three years ago. The fighting broke out around midnight in the narrow alleyways of the Rashidiyeh refugee camp and continued until 9 a.m., when fighters loyal to Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction of the PLO intervened. Police and Palestinian sources said supporters and opponents of Abu Nidal from within his Fatah-Revolutionary Council fought in the narrow alleys of the shantytown, using mortars, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades. Rashidiyeh, 50 miles south of Beirut, houses 18,500 Palestinians registered by the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, in addition to a few thousand unregistered refugees. The police sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Abu Nidal's opponents, backed by fighters from Arafat's Fatah, occupied a school run by the U.N. agency. The three-story building overlooks the main position of Abu Nidal's loyalists. The opponents demanded that Abu Nidal's supporters surrender or risk being dislodged by force, the sources said. Forty men surrendered after the mediation of representatives from other PLO factions. The Fatah-Revolutionary Council is outside the Palestine Liberation Organization, which comprises nine factions. The fighting flared up after Saturday's assassination in Rashidiyeh of Omar Hamadeh, regional commander of the Fatah-Revolutionary Council. His bodyguard, Mohammed Meri, was wounded. His attacker is unknown. Arafat's Fatah and the Fatah-Revolutionary Council of Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, are also engaged in a bitter feud. PLO officials and opponents said in 1987 that Abu Nidal had 22 close aides gunned down in Libya in the internal policy dispute. Abu Nidal is believed to be in Libya, despite reports that Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi was seeking his ouster in order to distance himself from international terrorism. A U.S. State Department report last year described Abu Nidal as the world's most dangerous terrorist. It blamed his group for 34 terrorist attacks in 20 countries since he split from the PLO in 1973. At least 900 people were killed or wounded in these attacks, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Call for Resignation of Bangladesh Leader
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets throughout Bangladesh during a general strike Sunday to protest new taxes and demand the resignation of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad. The opposition-sponsored protest shut down schools, businesses and transportation in at least 21 major cities, including the capital, Dhaka, a city of 6 million. The strike was widely observed, but it was difficult to measure popular support because many people stayed home or closed shops for fear of violence. More than 50 people were detained by police during the protests, but there were no reports of violence. In Dhaka, thousands of marchers shouted, ``Down with Ershad!'' as riot police patrolled nearby. ``Ershad has no right to stay in power. People have rejected the fresh taxes proposed by his government,'' said Sheikh Hasina, leader of an alliance of eight parties that called the strike. Finance Minister Abdul Munim announced Thursday in Parliament that new taxes would be introduced. Munim said increased taxes were essential to raise funds for development programs. Bangladesh, with a population of 111 million, is one of the poorest countries in the world with a per capita income of $160 a year. Opposition leaders have labeled the proposed increases ``anti-people'' and have demanded that the government resign and order new elections under a neutral caretaker government. The opposition also accused Ershad, a former army general, of rigging presidential and parliamentary elections to retain power. Ershad's Jatiya or People's Party holds a two-thirds majority in Parliament, but leading opposition parties boycotted the last elections in 1988. Ershad took power in a bloodless coup in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Return to Bucharest Square After Violence
LaserPhotos XBUC1,5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with statement from Interior Ministry offering dialogue with protesters. Pickup pvs 5th graf, `Opposition leaders...' EDITS to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Anti-communist demonstrators Sunday returned to a main square where police and miners loyal to President Ion Iliescu beat people to put down protests last week. ``Down with Iliescu!'' ``Iliescu should be put on trial!'' about 100 protesters yelled. Soldiers armed with clubs looked on, but they took no immediate action to disperse them. The small group of demonstrators thinned out by midnight after Interior Minister Doru Viorel Ursu offered to open a dialogue with the protesters. Ursu was appointed Thursday after his predecessor was forced to step down partly because of the brutal way in which police broke up the previous demonstration in the square. ``We are waiting for dialogue with you, and we are ready to meet you wherever you want,'' said the Interior Ministry communique published by the state Rompres news agency. ``We are convinced we can live in harmony.'' The demonstrators earlier Sunday issued a list of demands, including the release of all those arrested over the past week in connection with the protest and subsequent rioting and the publication of a list of people still hospitalized as a result of the violence. The government says 1,021 people were arrested in last week's protests. There were no reports that miners were among those arrested. The government, having lost badly needed aid from the United States and Western Europe because of the recent repression, promised to uphold democratic principles in a statement published Sunday. Opposition leaders say the government of Iliescu, whose National Salvation Front won last month's free elections by a landslide, is dominated by ex-communists from the regime of deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Iliescu is to be inaugurated later this week. In Timisoara, about 3,000 people gathered Sunday on a central square for a service to remember 94 people killed in the western city in December. The uprising grew into the bloody revolution that overthrew Ceausescu. The service was peaceful. Scores of demonstrators appeared in Bucharest on Sunday evening at University Square, the site of a 53-day protest demanding that Iliescu and other ex-communists be banned from office. Riot police broke up the demonstration Wednesday, the start of three days of unrest in which six people died and 502 were injured. Iliescu called on thousands of coal miners to maintain order, and they swarmed Bucharest on Thursday and Friday. Swinging iron bars and cudgels, they attacked anyone they suspected as anti-government. The violence ended after Iliescu thanked the miners ``with all my heart'' and ordered them home late Friday. On Sunday, about 80 troops equipped with submachine guns and nightsticks stood on the periphery of University Square but did not interfere. Two buses full of police were parked nearby. Opposition leaders said the government was behaving like the dictatorship it replaced. In a statement published in Sunday's newspapers, the government pledged to play by democratic rules. ``The government is prepared to assure appropriate measures for freedom of political expression for all with the exception of acts of instigation and of neo-fascist propaganda,'' he statement said. ``It also demands that those responsible ensure the total freedom of operation of the democratic institutions of the press, radio and television and ... instill firmly democratic institutions in our country,'' it added. The statement appeared to be an attempt to contain damage to Romania's image abroad and to quiet domestic critics particularly worried by the miners' attacks on intellectuals. Miners smashed the headquarters of opposition parties, ransacked the home of at least one opposition leader and ordered four opposition dailies and periodicals to stop publishing. The newspapers have not reappeared, raising fears that opposition voices will not be heard in a society dominated by Iliescu and his National Salvation Front. Western governments and international human rights organizations condemned the violence of the miners. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States would withhold all but humanitarian aid, and the European Community postponed a trade and economic cooperation agreement with Romania.

DOC.HEAD: Architects of Lebanon War Named to Defense Committee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9 grafs for 8-14 bgng ```This government...' UPDATE with quote from Arens. Pickup pvs 15, `Sharon, 62.... EDITS to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: The new right-wing Cabinet on Sunday gave former generals Ariel Sharon and Rafael Eitan their biggest say in military policy since both were reprimanded for actions in two massacres during the 1982 Lebanon invasion. At its first meeting, the Cabinet named Sharon, a former defense minister, and Eitan, chief of staff during the Lebanon invasion, to the 11-man Ministerial Defense Committee. The committee is a forum for debating defense policies and also includes one representative of each of Likud's government coalition allies. Sharon and Eitan were blamed by an Israeli inquiry for not anticipating that Israel's Lebanese Christian militia allies would massacre hundreds of Palestinians if they were allowed to enter Beirut's Sabra and Chatilla refugee camps in 1982. Sharon, a leader of the conservative Likud bloc, also was named chairman of a Cabinet committee overseeing the immigration of thousands of Soviet Jews to Israel. Sharon is an advocate of Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. His appointment has raised fears that he would try to move Soviet Jews to the occupied areas, worsening already tense ties with the United States. U.S. officials consider the Jewish settlements obstacles to peace. Israeli officials insisted Sunday that the new Cabinet would work for peace with Palestinians and for a smoother relationship with the United States. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said he wants to ``improve the level and scope of dialogue between myself as defense minister and the Arab Palestinian population in the area, so that together we try to find the basis of an agreement.'' ``I know it would be limited and I know we don't agree about many things ... but what is important here is the very fact of a dialogue,'' Arens said on Israel Television's Arabic-language program. Police Minister Roni Milo, a Likud member and confidant of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said: ``This government is interested in the peace process no less than the preceding government.'' Likud's coalition government with the left-center Labor Party fell apart in March because Shamir would not go along with Labor demands to accept a U.S. proposal for preliminary Palestinian-Israeli peace talks. The new right-wing government took power last week. Milo said he expected talks soon between U.S. and Israeli officials to advance the peace process. He also warned, however, that the new government would not accept ``previous processes that were not brought up nicely'' _ a reference to Secretary of States James A. Baker III's efforts to organize an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Cairo, Egypt. Baker urged including at least one Palestinian deported by Israel as a way to satisfy Palestine Liberation Organization demands that Palestinians living outside the occupied lands be included. He also proposed to include some Arabs who have homes both in the annexed east Jerusalem and in the occupied areas. Israel argued such moves would allow the PLO to control the Palestinian delegation and raise the issue of Jerusalem, which Israel has declared its ``eternal capital.'' The new defense committee named by the Cabinet will be headed by Shamir, 74, a former agent of the Mossad secret service. The committee also includes Arens and Foreign Minister David Levy. Sharon, 62, a hero in the 1967 and 1973 Middle East wars, was the architect of the Lebanon invasion. He was forced to resign as defense minister after the Sabra and Chatilla massacre in west Beirut. Israeli-allied Lebanese Christian militiamen, who were bitter over the murder of their leader, went into the two refugee camps the day after Israel's army seized control of west Beirut. They killed more than 800 Palestinians, many of them women and children. An Israeli inquiry found that Sharon ``disregarded the danger of acts of venegance'' in allowing the Christian fighters into the camps. It found that Eitan failed to investigate reports of a massacre and did not act to stop it. Sharon has repeatedly said he wants the defense minister's post back, but he has been kept in lesser Cabinet jobs. Eitan, 61, a member of the far-right Tzomet Party, has never been in the Cabinet.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Reports Discovery of Anti-Government Groups
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese counterintelligence agents have uncovered five anti-government rings and arrested dozens of members after investigating joint ventures with foreign companies, an official report said. The Saturday broadcast, a text of which was seen in Bangkok on Sunday, was one of a series of recent announcements indicating a crackdown on dissent in the communist southeast Asian country. Hanoi Radio said the groups were discovered when security services investigated more than 100 companies involved in the joint ventures with foreign companies. The radio said the investigation was part of a drive is intended to root out people regarded as dangerous to national security. The crackdown, spearheaded by the interior ministry, has included arrests, increased police surveillance and the deportation of two Americans for alleged anti-government activity. The broadcast said that in their inspection of the companies, security forces had ``discovered many spies who have taken advantage of various international organizations and corporations that have investments in Vietnam to infiltrate into the country to carry out intelligence activities.'' ``The security forces have destroyed five underground reactionary organizations and captured tens of their members,'' the broadcast said. It said many documents, books, magazines and other publications ``with reactionary contents'' had been confiscated. The broadcast did not elaborate on the alleged spy and anti-government groups. It did not identify those arrested. In the past, Hanoi has charged that the CIA and Vietnamese expatriates have tried to destabilize the communist government. Some Vietnamese officials said the crackdown was ordered to prevent protests during several anniversaries earlier this year. These included the 15th anniversary of the communists' victory over South Vietnam. But Western analysts said they believe there is also a sense of insecurity among hard-line, older communist leaders who fear the country is being isolated by the fall of communist governments around the world. Vietnam is one of a dwindling number of nations where the communist party rules without sharing power.

DOC.HEAD: Director of Air Show Dies in Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: The director of an air show died Sunday when his plane crashed in a ball of fire while he was performing a stunt, officials said. Tom Jones, 44, a former national champion aerobatic pilot who was directing the Aerospace America '90 show, was killed in the 1:45 p.m. crash, the show's chairman, Ted Strenczek, said in a statement. ``When it hit, it just exploded,'' said Kevin Ellis, one of thousands who saw the crash at the Will Rogers World Airport. ``No matter how fast the trucks got there, he was dead. It was just a ball of fire.'' Witnesses said Jones' Soviet-made, civilian Sukhoi-26 stunt plane apparently did not regain power after he flipped it during an intentional stall. ``It didn't even come out of the stall,'' said spectator Ranee Woodall. ``I didn't hear his engine.'' Observers said that just before it crashed, Jones' plane trailed smoke of a color different than the pure white normally used to illustrate stunts. The plane hit the ground nose-first about 100 yards from the crowd, estimated at 75,000. No injuries were reported. Emergency workers in fireproof suits ran to the crash site, and Federal Aviation Administration officials were at the plane within minutes. Jones was a member of the 1988-89 world champion aerobatic team, and was the national aerobatic champion in 1988, said air show spokesman Mark House. The rest of the show, which was in its final of three days, was canceled, but U.S. military planes performed a salute to Jones. Three Soviet planes, which Jones' lobbying efforts had brought to the show, repeated the tribute. They included the world's biggest cargo jet, a Soviet Antonov-225 which was displayed but did not fly at a Wisconsin show last year, and two Soviet Sukhoi-Su 27 Flanker fighter jets, on their second U.S. appearance. Jones flew to Moscow twice to persuade the Soviets to bring the planes to the show here.

DOC.HEAD: Patching Complete, Fuel Unloaded From Liner
DOC.TEXT: Temporary patching on the hull of the crippled cruise liner Bermuda Star was completed, readying the vessel for towing to dry dock in New York, the Coast Guard said Sunday. The hull patching was finished Saturday night and the liner's fuel was transferred to a barge, said Petty Officer Dale Caudoe in the Marine Safety Office in Providence, R.I. Caudoe said the ship probably would be towed to dry dock in New York for permanent repairs Monday or Tuesday. The cruise ship was carrying 1,067 passengers and crew when it hit a rocky ledge near Falmouth in dense fog June 10. The vessel was freed later that day and towed to a spot about three miles away. The accident ripped the ship's hull and exposed tanks holding about 110,000 gallons of fuel. About 7,500 gallons spilled, the Coast Guard said. Crews cleaned about 1,000 gallons of fuel that washed onto Naushon Island and additional oil pockets found later on nearby Nashawena Island. Environmentalists said the oil should pose little threat to wildlife.

DOC.HEAD: Microbe Experiment Continues Despite Delay
With AM-Tanker Blast
DOC.TEXT: Oil-eating microbes spread over part of an oil slick from the supertanker Mega Borg appear to have done their job, but officials said they launched another experiment Sunday to make sure. On Friday, about 100 pounds of hungry bacteria were spread over an acre of the slick from the crippled Norwegian tanker that exploded June 8 in the Gulf of Mexico. It was the first use of the process called bioremediation on open waters. A flyover Sunday of the area marked by a buoy showed little oil in the treated waters, state officials said. ``There certainly wasn't any oil over there,'' said Texas Water Commission Chairman B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne. However, Wynne said it could not be determined if the oil was removed by the microbes or currents, or whether the buoy had moved. ``Visually, it appeared there was hardly anything left. It appears degradation of the oil has occurred,'' said Blanton Moore of the Texas General Land Office. Moore said officials won't know for certain from the first application, so they started another experiment Sunday by encircling two areas of the slick with booms, each 15 feet in diameter. Officials plan to spread microbes on one area, but do nothing with the other. Moore said water samples will be taken from both areas, and results should be available early in the week. Carl Oppenheimer, a University of Texas microbiologist who has been working on bioremediation for 15 years, has predicted the experiment will succeed and show that the process should be used on a wider scale in oil spills. Bioremediation uses naturally occurring bacteria to break down oil into harmless fatty acids eaten by marine life.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to Visit Japan Early Next Year
DOC.TEXT: Japan's prime minister announced Sunday that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will visit in early 1991. It would be the first trip to Japan by a top Soviet leader. Relations have long been soured by a territorial dispute involving islands at the southern end of the Kuril chain seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu announced the visit during a seminar sponsored by the governing Liberal Democratic Party.
