He said it was confirmed in a letter from the Soviets saying Gorbachev would arrive in early 1991. Kaifu gave no exact date. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze told Japanese officials in September that Gorbachev hoped to visit Tokyo in 1991 but did not specify when. A Liberal Democratic Party official quoted Kaifu as saying at the seminar that his administration will try to improve relations with the Soviet Union by negotiating over the disputed islands while promoting cultural and personal exchanges. Though Gorbachev's visit would be the first to Japan by a top Soviet leader, four Japanese prime ministers have visited the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Rally Kicks Off Week of Black Student Activism
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of black college students marched to a rally at a park across from the White House on Sunday to bolster their call for better education opportunities. A handful of civil rights leaders and musicians joined the rally in Lafayette Square urging a resurgence of black activism to fight for justice for all students at campuses across the nation. ``Whenever young America comes alive, America is always made better,'' Rev. Jesse Jackson told the crowd. Jackson said the fights for self-determination _ like those democratic movements occurring across the globe _ do not come from meetings of politicians, they come from the ``blood of common people.'' Organizers said the rally day also was designed to kick off a week of black activism in which students will take to Capitol Hill to lobby their members of Congress for District of Columbia statehood, and continued sanctions against South Africa. Students say the racial division and tension that occurs at colleges must be defeated. The ``Student Call to Washington'' also includes a rally planned in front of the U.S. Supreme Court Wednesday. The week was organized by the National Collegiate Black Caucus and several other groups including Black Law Students Association, the African National Congress Youth Division and the United States Student Association. U.S. Capitol Police estimated 850 people participated in Sunday's Demonstration.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Communists Headed For Bulgarian Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with projected unofficial results. Pickup pvs 13th graf, `Petar Beron....' EDITS to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Ex-Communists appeared on the way toward winning a parliamentary majority in runoff elections Sunday. It would be the first victory for a reformed Communist party in the recent East bloc elections. However, the 400-seat unicameral parliament, the first freely elected legislature in Bulgaria in 58 years, will have a substantial number of opposition lawmakers and their presence will mark the end of rubber-stamp approval for policies of the former Communists. The Bulgarian capital, Sofia, appeared to be firmly in opposition hands. The projections of a victory for the former Communists _ who now call themselves Socialists _ was based in part on incomplete results from about 30 of the 81 constituencies counted by the independent Association for Fair Elections. The group did not release a total figure for how many seats it believed the former Communists captured, but it said preliminary numbers indicated they had won an overall majority. First-round results show that in 22 of the 81 constituencies in Sunday's runoff, the ex-Communists candidates had a substantial lead over their rivals and in 33 others they had a slight edge. Apart from Bulgaria, non-Communist parties have triumphed in this year's round of national elections in East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Romania after last year's democratic revolutions. However, in Romania, a party with former Communists in its leadership won elections last month. Although Sunday's voting appeared to go smoothly in most places, state television reported breaches of electoral procedure in some constituencies and illegal canvassing near some polling stations. Dimiter Ivanov, an activist from the Association of Fair Elections, told The Associated Press in some cases the number of people voting exceeded the number of people registered in the respective precincts. The Socialists were the winners in the first round of voting on June 10, garnering 172 seats. They need to win only 29 of the 81 seats being decided in the runoffs to gain an absolute majority. Socialist Party leader Alexander Lilov was a first-round winner, but Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov faced a runoff, which he is expected to win. The main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, won 107 seats in the first round and other opposition groups won 40. The alliance and the Agrarian Party, a once docile ally of the Communists, have both vowed not to join a coalition with the Socialists. In Sofia, the United Democratic Forces won 18 of 26 available seats in the first round of elections. Association of Fair Election officials said the alliance added at least another six seats Sunday, turning the capital into a bulwark of the opposition. Socialist and United Democratic Forces officials have said they might form a government of experts chosen on the basis of their expertise, rather than their political affiliation. Dimiter Popov, secretary of the Central Electoral Commission, said the commission expects to announce the results Tuesday, the state news agency BTA reported. State television said 75 percent of the eligible voters cast ballots shortly before the polls closed at 6 p.m. In the first first round, 91 percent voted. Petar Beron, a member of the leadership of the United Democratic Forces, said in an interview Sunday that he expected the Socialists to win an absolute majority. He noted, however, that whatever shape the new government takes it is likely to be transitional. ``Such a government is usually a caretaker government, but it cannot rule the country for very long,'' he said. Lilov said in an interview published Sunday that his party favored a coalition of national unity. In an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. that was reprinted in the Socialist Party daily Duma, Lilov said that if the opposition refused to join such a government, his party would approach ``respected personalities'' to form a government of ``experts and professionals.'' The chief task of the new government will be tackling the country's $10 billion foreign debt, rising inflation and consumer goods shortages while gearing the economy toward capitalism. The United Democratic Front favors sweeping private ownership and privatization of agriculture. The Socialists would prefer to leave some industry government-run for the time being and are vague on the future status of farming, which is currently government-owned or cooperative. Outside a polling station in the town of Stanke Dimitrov, about 40 miles south of Sofia, a young soldier who refused to give his name said he voted for the Socialists ``because I want security, I am scared of the UDF.'' Analysts say the Socialists represent stability for many and won a certain popularity after ousting former Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov last November and initiating reform.

DOC.HEAD: More Thunderstorms, More Flooding and Summer Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: Father's Day on Sunday brought more thunderstorms and flooding to the South and the Midwest. Rain showers and thunderstorms were scattered over the northern half of Florida by midday, as well as over southern Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, western Tennessee, southeast Illinois, southern Indiana and into southern Ohio. Showers and thunderstorms also extended over Michigan, as well as northern Minnesota, eastern North Dakota and northeastern South Dakota. Scattered showers and storms fell across Oregon, northeast California and southwest Idaho. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included about an inch at Grand Forks, N.D., and Traverse City, Mich. Flooding continued across east-central Nebraska, where a number of roads and highways were closed. Only the floods of the 1940s were higher than the crest on the Elkhorn River at West Point, Neb. Flooding was widespread across much of Iowa and northwest Illinois, where roads and highways also were closed. Flood warnings remained in effect on the Mississippi River at Natchez, Miss., and Red River Landing, Baton Rouge and Donaldsonville, La., as well as on the Atchafalaya River at Morgan City, La. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 53 degrees at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 102 degrees at Wink, Texas. The low temperature for the Lower 48 was 30 degrees at Gunnison, Colo., and Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Calls For Common Effort to Build Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki said Sunday that calls by Solidarity members to accelerate reforms jeopardize government efforts to institute democratic changes. Mazowiecki was speaking to leaders of Citizens Committees, the political arm that Solidarity formed last year to contest elections, as they met in Warsaw to debate future strategy. ``Those who use attacks, poison and hatred make holes in our common boat of Polish democracy ...,'' Mazowiecki said. ``Only by common effort and only by understanding that one has to build the fundamentals of Polish democracy will we be able to go through this difficult passage from the old to the new system,'' he added. Mazowiecki, a Catholic intellectual and longtime adviser to Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, said the Citizens Committees should act in partnership with other groups to build democracy in Poland. Mazowiecki took over as head of Poland's Solidarity-led government in August, ending 40 years of monopoly rule by the Communist Party. However, he has come under increasing attack by Walesa and members of parliament for being too slow and too timid in routing out Communist bureaucrats. Walesa has also attempted to bring new people who back his views into Solidarity's national committee. Those efforts have aroused concern among intellectuals who believe Walesa's new set of advisers are more interested in seeing the Solidarity leader elected president than in rebuilding democracy. Walesa did not attend Sunday's meeting but sent a letter that was read before the delegates. ``We are passing today from one system to another. The old system we fought against has been overthrown. A new political system is only being formed. It should be formed as quickly as possible, more energetically,'' the labor leader wrote in his letter.

DOC.HEAD: Changing Technology A Topic at Vegas Convention
DOC.TEXT: About 14,000 newspaper executives are expected to focus on changing newspaper technology at the 62nd annual American Newspaper Publishers Association Technical Exposition and Conference this week. The event, which begins Monday and ends Wednesday, features the largest display of newspaper equipment in the world, with 350 exhibitors displaying their wares over 365,000 square feet of exhibition space. Two Las Vegas newspaper executives, Review-Journal general manager Dave Osborn and Sun president Brian Greenspun, are to deliver welcoming addresses Monday at the opening general session. The show provides an opportunity for manufacturers and suppliers to the newspaper and graphics arts business to present their products and services to an international audience of top newspaper executives. Norman P. Dusseault, vice president and assistant general manager of the Times Publishing Co. of St. Petersburg, Fla., will chair the event. ANPA Chairman Lloyd G. Schermer is to deliver Monday's keynote address, ``Challenges Facing Our Business.'' Recycling, desktop publishing and telephone technology, along with other advances in the industry, will be the topics of general sessions and workshops throughout the event.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Man Robs Church Congregation
DOC.TEXT: A man armed with a sawed-off shotgun entered a Baptist church Sunday and robbed the 132-member congregation as they lay on the floor amid the pews ``for an eternity.'' No one was hurt, authorities said. The man, wearing a stocking mask and sunglasses, made off with at least $500, but didn't get the Faith Way Baptist Church's collection, according to church officials and the Barbour County sheriff's department. The incident just outside this town in northeast West Virginia occurred around 11:30 a.m., about midway through the morning service, the sheriff's department said in a statement. The pastor's wife, Mrs. Mary Gregory, said the man came in through the church's basement, where the children were holding junior church, and walked up the steps to the back of the sanctuary. ``He had a gun and he said, `This is a holdup. Everybody get down.' Everybody looked at him and they were just stunned,'' Mrs. Gregory said. ``Everybody was down and they were praying and he was going around the pews and taking billfolds and purses and things. ``It seemed like he was there for an eternity, but actually it was about 10 or 15 minutes,'' she said. ``I don't know, for some reason I just thought it was a prank,'' said her husband, the Rev. Downing Gregory. ``I didn't believe him to be serious about it. All of the sudden, my associate (pastor) started praying on the platform there with me and then I realized, `I think we're in trouble.''' The man had a congregation member help him collect the wallets and purses in a bag, Mrs. Gregory said. He threatened people the man helping collect the money and the associate minister, Daniel Jager, who was praying louder than others in the congregation, she said. ``The man was getting irritated,'' Mrs. Gregory. ``They were praying for him, what he was doing and that it was wrong.'' The collection, which already had been gathered, was in the church office and the gunman apparently did not find it, Mrs. Gregory said. Church officials declined to say how much was collected. In addition to cash, the man made off with several checkbooks and credit cards, Mrs. Gregory said. As he left, the bandit told the congregation members to pray for 15 minutes before getting up from the floor, Mrs. Gregory said. Attendance at the service was 132, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Divers Find 250 Pounds of Marijuana Attached to Cruise Ship's Hull
DOC.TEXT: Police divers found 250 pounds of marijuana in steel boxes inside the propeller section of a cruise ship, and three Jamaicans were arrested for drug trafficking, the Coast Guard said Sunday. The search began just after noon Saturday when the captain of the cruise ship Holiday reported seeing two scuba divers swimming under the ship's hull and asked authorities to search for anything suspicious below the water line. The Coast Guard dispatched two patrol boats from Miami Beach and quickly found and arrested the divers, both Jamaican citizens, plus another Jamaican man in a nearby motorboat. The divers found the four steel boxes, each measuring 2 cubic feet, inside the grating that covers the cruise ship's propeller shafts, said Coast Guard Lt. Wayne Ball. The Holiday, which had returned to Miami from Jamaica earlier Saturday, left for Mexico, its next stop, at 10 p.m., six hours late and minus the steel boxes, Ball said. The three men were turned over to Miami Beach police, who declined to identify them.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Killed in Colombian Drug Hub, Drug Suspect Captured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for graf 3 `The trafficking...' to CORRECT spelling of Sheuter; pickup graf 5 `Bill Dempsey...' ^By STAN YARBRO
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen have killed 12 more people in the violence-wracked drug capital of Medellin, and police said Sunday they have captured another suspected drug trafficker wanted in the United States. The 10-month-old war between the government and traffickers heated up again last week when police shot and killed the man they described as the mastermind of the drug lords' campaign of terror, and a car bomb killed four people. The trafficking suspect, Salomon Sheuter Benitez was captured Friday in the coastal city of Barranquilla, a police communique said. The communique said Sheuter, 49, is wanted in Pittsburgh on charges of conspiring to distribute cocaine. He is one of 15 Colombians currently awaiting extradition to the United States. Bill Dempsey, a spokesman for the U.S. Marshal service in Washington, said the person arrested apparently is the same one listed on a Dec. 14, 1987, cocaine possession and distribution warrant from Pittsburgh in a state case. There was no immediate confirmation of the arrest or details from other U.S. officials. Sheuter is not on the official U.S. list of the 12 Colombian drug suspects most wanted for extradition. Four more police and two soldiers were shot and killed by terrorists in Medellin on Saturday, a police communique said without elaborating. Officials were quoted Sunday by a newspaper as saying married policemen will be transferred out of the city. Police have said the Medellin cartel is paying more than $4,000 to terrorists for every police officer they kill. A terrorist campaign blamed on the city's cocaine cartel has killed 116 police officers this year in the city 150 miles northwest of the capital Bogota. In addition, a gunmen killed six civilians, including two 16-year-old girls, in a restaurant in one of Medellin's poor neighborhoods, police reported. They gave no details. However, the massacre was similar to several recently carried out by unidentified gunmen in neighborhoods known as the recruiting grounds for the Medellin cartel. In a communique last week, the cartel blamed police for the killings of the neighborhoods' youths. Police rejected the charge, saying the massacres were apparently the work of rival criminal gangs. The Colombian government has extradited 15 Colombians since putting the policy into effect in August. The last extradition was March 29. Several U.S. and Colombian officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, have said the policy has been suspended until the president-elect, Cesar Gaviria, takes office on Aug. 7. The administration of President Virgilio Barco has not commented on whether the policy has been suspended. Traffickers have retaliated for the government's anti-drug campaign with a wave of terrorist attacks that have left hundreds of Colombians dead since the war began in August with the traffickers' assassination of a leading presidential hopeful. The government has offered over $400,000 for information leading to the capture of the alleged chief of the Medellin cartel, Pablo Escobar. On Wednesday, police raided the Medellin apartment of the cartel's military chief, John Jairo Arias, and killed him after he fired on them, according to the official report. Hours later, a car bomb exploded near a police post in the same neighborhood. It killed four people, including two suspected terrorists inside the car, and injured 43 others, police said.

DOC.HEAD: `Dick Tracy' Opens to Estimated $23 Million
DOC.TEXT: ``Dick Tracy,'' the ultra-hyped Disney movie facing a gremlin and a muscleman as summer box-office enemies, will make up to $23 million in ticket sales in its opening weekend, it was estimated Sunday. Dick Cook, president of Buena Vista Pictures Distribution for Disney, said ``Tracy'' was a record opening for the company and had all the signs of a summer winner. The movie, directed by its star, Warren Beatty, received mostly rave reviews. ``The way it's been reviewed, and the favorable way it has been received _ it is going to do extraordinarily well. And there's a lot of summer left,'' Cook said. He estimated a weekend box-office of $22 million to $23 million, and said ``Dick Tracy'' would get ``double the amount of business that any other movie will do this weekend.'' An industry observer who spoke on condition of anonymity said the opening was ``not great _ somewhere in between. ... It's not a bad opening.'' That source estimated the take for ``Tracy'' would be $22 million. Both noted ``Tracy's'' debut against a slate of movies hothouse-grown to bloom as summer hits: ``Total Recall,'' ``Back to the Future III,'' ``Another 48 HRS.,'' and the new ``Gremlins.'' The week's other major opening, Warner Bros.' ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch,'' featuring Gizmo the gremlin and his deranged cousins, may earn up to $10.3 million, according to one industry guess. Hovering over all this year's summer flicks was the shadow of the $40.5 million debut last year of Warner Bros.' comic-book hero movie, ``Batman.'' The estimated Tracy box office was well below that. It also is under the $25 million opening for Arnold Schwarzenegger's ``Total Recall'' in the first weekend of this month. ``It's never where you start, it's where you end,'' said Cook of ``Dick Tracy's'' earning power for the summer. ``Dick Tracy'' opened at 2,223 theaters around the nation with a new Roger Rabbit cartoon, ``Rollercoaster Rabbit.'' Admission for midnight Thursday openings was a T-shirt, sold by theaters for as much as $20 apiece. Disney said it will include the price of the T-shirt in its box-office gross, despite the protests of others in the movie industry that it would inflate the numbers. ``It is part of the box office, the ticket to the event,'' said Cook. ``It didn't amount to that much.'' One source placed the T-shirt boost at $1.2 million to $1.5 million. Cook said the opening of ``Dick Tracy,'' starring Beatty as the comic-strip detective and Madonna as gun moll Breathless Mahoney, outstripped Disney first weekend earnings for ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' which took $14.2 million last year _ against ``Batman'' _ and ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' which took $11 million. ``Honey'' went on to earn $130 million domestically; ``Roger Rabbit'' brought home $160 million as the hit of 1988. Batman earned $250 million domestically for 1989. The sales figures for ``Tracy'' are estimates which include box office from Friday through Sunday. Final figures including the actual Sunday gate will not be available until Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Midwest Cleans Up from Severe Thunderstorms, Tornadoes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `The 11-year-old ...,' to ADD dead girl's name; SUBS grafs 13-15, `The engineer ...,' with six grafs to UPDATE with scattered thunderstorms Sunday in parts of Illinois, width of South Dakota tornado's path, partial South Dakota damage estimate, CORRECTS to say warning sirens not sounded in most South Dakota areas hit; picks up 16th graf, `In northeast ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Flash Floods, Bjt

DOC.TEXT: Midwesterners mopped up or continued battling flood waters Sunday after tornadoes, thunderstorms and flooding hit parts of the region, killing an 11-year-old girl in Iowa and a railroad engineer in Illinois. Tornadoes that roared through South Dakota and Nebraska on Saturday left damaged or destroyed farm buildings and homes and uprooted trees in their wake. Up to half a foot of rain fell on already-sodden ground in Minnesota and Nebraska. In eastern Iowa, Clear Creek jumped its banks, closing a two-mile section of Interstate 80 on Sunday. Flooding knocked out water service to the small town of Manning in the western part of the state. Damage to just the eastern Iowa cities of Bettendorf and Davenport along the Mississipi River was $21 million, officials estimated. Heavy rains caused the collapse early Sunday of the roof and part of a wall at the K&M Manufacturing sheet metal plant in Marshalltown in central Iowa. No one was at the plant at the time, and there were no injuries. Eight inches of rain have doused Iowa over the past week; some parts of the state got more than 5 inches of rain in a matter of hours, said forecaster Scott Truett of the National Weather Service's Des Moines office. Weather service flood specialist Ed May said some rivers were still rising but predicted there wouldn't be much more flooding beyond farmland. ``It's not unusual to have flooding in June. June's a wet month,'' he said. ``What's unusual is the extent. We've got almost all of the rivers in two-thirds of the state above flood stage. That's kind of rare.'' Michaella Aguiler, 11, was killed when she was swept into a culvert in the Davenport suburb of LeClaire on the Mississippi River, authorities said. Gov. Terry Branstad declared seven eastern and central counties disaster areas on Saturday, and sent the National Guard to help sandbag low-lying areas as rivers and creeks overflowed. Guard soldiers remained on flood duty on Sunday. Heavy rains lashed western Illinois on Saturday. Thirty-two cars of an 88-car Burlington Northern freight train derailed when a waterlogged embankment gave way near Morrison, killing the engineer and injuring three other railway workers, officials said. Train workers were trapped in the engine because the locomotive car they were in came to rest in about 15 feet of water and mud, said a Whiteside County sheriff's dispatcher who refused to give her name. The engineer was identified as Samuel Jiardina, 61, of La Crosse, Wis. The injured were treated and released. Damage was estimated at $2.1 million, including about 600 feet of damaged track. Scattered thunderstorms pounded parts of northern and west-central Illinois on Sunday night, but no damage or injuries were reported. In southeastern South Dakota, a tornado hit so fast Saturday, it knocked out power before warning sirens could be activated in most areas. The twister left a nine-mile-long, three-mile wide trail of destruction, but no injuries were reported. The tornado damaged 30 farms, five of them seriously, said Fire Chief T.A. Mullinix in Beresford, 35 miles south of Sioux Falls. One home lost its roof, Mullinix said. The twister also knocked down power lines and several buildings and barns in Alcester 10 miles east of Beresford. Alcester Police Chief Kevin Booker said he got to activate warning sirens for a few seconds before power was lost. Millinix estimated that damage could total at least $1.2 million. In northeast Nebraska, cleanup began Sunday in Madison following a Saturday night tornado that caused widespread damage just hours after 60 to 80 people had been evacuated from the other side of town because of flooding, officials said. Accompanying torrential rains caused widespread flooding throughout the northeast part of the state. Part of the roof of the IBP Inc. meat packing plant in Madison was torn off by the storm, said a woman who answered the plant's phone. She wouldn't give her name. ``There are trees down everywhere, roofs off of houses all over town, and gas lines ruptured,'' said Madison police Officer Mike Bowersox. ``It moved right through the middle of town.'' There were no reports of deaths or injuries in the community of 2,000 about 100 miles northwest of Omaha. Another tornado touched down farther north near O'Neill earlier Saturday, damaging two farms, in Nebraska's fifth straight day of severe storms. In the southern Minnesota city of Fairmont, heavy rains flooded streets because sewers were unable to keep up as winds gusted to 60 mph, the weather service said. Flooding also hit the basement of Fairmont Community Hospital, which had to be pumped out by the fire department, said a hospital supervisor who refused to give her name. The water posed no threat to patients, she said. ``It looked like hurricane winds for a while,'' the supervisor said. ``It was really bending the trees.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Excessive Air Traffic May Have Contributed to Avianca Crash
DOC.TEXT: On the day an Avianca jet crashed while trying to land at Kennedy Airport, officials had cleared the airport to accept more airplanes an hour than a traffic control supervisor recommended, a newsaper reported Sunday. The procedure for controlling the flow of planes into the airport broke down that day, and may have contributed to the crash of Avianca Flight 52, Newsday said, citing interviews and documents. The fuel-starved Avianca plane crashed in Cove Neck on Long Island on Jan. 25, killing 73 people, after it had been placed in holding patterns for more than an hour while flying up the East Coast from Medellin, Colombia. A supervisor at TRACON, the Long Island center that steers planes into New York-area airports, earlier that day recommended that just 22 planes an hour be allowed to land at Kennedy, citing threatening weather. On good-weather days, Kennedy accepts about 60 planes an hour. But after consultations with officials, including those at the Federal Aviation Administration's Central Flow headquarters in Washington, the landing rate was set at 33 planes an hour, unidentified sources familiar with the crash investigation told Newsday. ``The flow system fell apart,'' said an unidentified source familiar with a report by the National Transportation Safety Board. ``It did not work the way it was supposed to work. They (controllers) were playing a game of catch-up all afternoon. They never caught up.'' Investigators said the flow problem alone did not cause the accident, noting that the Avianca crew did not declare a fuel emergency, which would have given them immediate landing clearance, Newsday reported. But one investigator, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that if a lower landing rate had been set, the Avianca jet might have been cleared to land earlier. NTSB hearings on the crash are scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday in Melville on Long Island.

DOC.HEAD: Boardwalk Birthday Party For Trump Day After Missed Bond Payment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollar sign for `s' in headline `DONALD DUCK$!' is cq in 8th graf. Moved for Sunday AMs on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ACP1 of June 16
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump, who turned 44 the day before he failed to make a critical debt payment, told casino workers throwing him a huge birthday bash that he's not washed up in the business world. ``Nobody wants to write the positives,'' Trump told about 1,000 cheering employees at his Taj Mahal Casino Resort on Saturday. ``Over the years, I've surprised a lot of people. The largest surprise is yet to come.'' Trump, who turned 44 on Thursday, did not specifically mention his failure Friday to make an estimated $31 million bond payment on his Trump Castle casino-resort, but criticized news reporters for focusing on his financial woes. News about his debt crunch overshadowed any coverage of gaming revenues produced last month by the Taj Mahal, which set a citywide record, he said. Trump arrived by limousine flanked by body guards and did not speak with reporters before climbing onto a stage fronting the Atlantic Ocean. For his birthday, Trump received a chocolate cupcake with a pink candle and an 8-foot-by-10-foot portrait of himself. Those looking for reports in the Taj Mahal of Trump's money troubles were disappointed. Any newspaper with headlines about Trump's problems was not for sale inside. Outside, newspaper stands on the Boardwalk near the stage were stocked with New York City papers headlined ``DONALD DUCK$!'' and ``Jilted By Lady Luck.'' Under foggy skies and surrounded by birthday cards signed by the 13,000 employees at his three casinos, Trump thanked workers for their loyalty, calling them ``absolutely fantastic.'' The Manhattan real estate mogul who also owns the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City left without speaking with reporters. Before he arrived, at least a dozen workers told the crowd that Trump would weather his problems and they thanked him for providing jobs. The speeches of support punctuated performances by gyrating belly dancers, stand-up comedians and a five-piece band. Donna Long, a 26-year-old craps table worker at Trump Plaza, said the rally inspired her. ``I feel like this business has its ups and downs,'' she said. ``My boss is a strong man.'' Trump missed a payment Friday on junk bonds used to finance Trump Castle and was given a 10-day grace period to make the payment. For the first quarter this year, Trump Castle posted a loss of $8.4 million, the largest loss among the city's 12 casinos. After the Taj Mahal opened in April, Trump Castle's gross gaming revenue declined 12.3 percent. In May, it fell 17.3 percent compared to 1989. Despite those losses, the casino was up 0.6 percent in gross gaming revenues for January-May compared to the first five months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Economists, Lobbyists Fight Over Whether Pennies Make Sense
DOC.TEXT: Frank Orloski didn't believe he was taking a stand in the debate over whether to eliminate the penny. But when he looked at the pricing policy of his 36 Quik Mart convenience stores and service stations, he realized he had already put his two cents in. ``In most circumstances, our prices either end with a nine or a five or a zero,'' Orloski said last week. ``When we price most of our merchandise, we either make it so customers get just one penny back or none. So I guess subconsciously, we do take a stand.'' The Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday will hear from economists and retailers on whether the United States should continue minting a 1-cent piece. If the bill becomes law, cash transactions would be rounded to the nearest nickel. Jim Benfield, a spokesman for a collection of groups whose main goal is a workable dollar coin, points to people like Orloski in illustrating the short shrift the penny gets and deserves. ``Forty-three percent of all coins required for small transactions are pennies,'' said Benfield, a spokesman for the Washington-based Coin Coalition. The figure is based on the minimum number of coins needed to make every change combination from 1 to 99 cents. Members of the Coin Coalition contend the United States loses $22 million a year in making change. The figure is based on 10 billion cash transactions yearly and a cashier wasting two seconds per transaction fishing for pennies. That adds up to 20 billion seconds, or 5.5 million hours. At $4 an hour for the average clerk, the total loss comes to $22 million. Also, if the penny were eliminated, cash register drawers would have room for the dollar coins the Coin Coalition backs. To help his customers, Orloski has small containers of pennies at the cash registers of half his northeastern Pennsylvania stores, a trend started by tobacco companies in the 1980s as point-of-purchase advertising. If people don't have exact change, they're encouraged to dip in. If they have extra change on a future trip, they're encouraged to return the favor. ``They're used. It makes it easier for everyone,'' said Orloski of Wilkes-Barre. Raymond Lombra, a Penn State economist who, like Benfield, will testify before the banking committee, defends the penny. ``The incidence of prices ending in nine or any odd digit is no accident,'' Lombra said. ``To the average customer, a 99-cent loaf of bread appears to cost a lot less than a $1 loaf of bread.'' Any money saved on clerks' wages would be offset if each adult had one transaction rounded up per day, Lombra said. He said it would effectively impose a ``rounding tax'' of $3.50 per adult per year. For the nation's 175 million adults, the cost would exceed $600 million. And with government payments tied to the consumer price index, the rounding tax could increase government spending $1.5 billion in five years, Lombra said. ``There's more to it than getting rid of those jars of pennies that have accumulated in our homes,'' he said. The Mint makes more than 10 billion pennies a year, more than all other U.S. coins combined. Eliminating the penny would eliminate the argument that the Mint doesn't have the capacity to produce new dollar coins. Pennies are made primarily of zinc, and the zinc industry partly funds the group that hired Lombra to do research. The new dollar coins would be mostly copper. The copper industry backs Benfield's group.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysia to Lose 627 Million Dollars If U.S. Ends Trade Privileges
DOC.TEXT: Malaysia will lose about $625 million if the United States withdraws special trade privileges because of human rights concerns, an official said. Deputy Prime Minister Abdul Ghafar Baba on Sunday said Malaysia receives that amount of quota and tax benefits under current privileges granted by the United States under the Generalized System of Preferences. The AFL-CIO and some other U.S. organizations have petitioned the U.S. Trade Representative to withdraw the privileges because of restrictions on human and labor rights in Malaysia. The limits include restrictions on workers in the electronics industry from forming their own national union. Some officials of the Malaysian Trades Union Congress, an association of trade unions, have backed the AFL-CIO's stand, but others have opposed it. Ghafar told reporters that the Malaysian government will appoint a lawyer in the United States to defend the privileges and urged Malaysian trade unions to lobby the U.S. government not to withdraw them.
